liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: New South Wales won't follow Victoria's lead in banning gas connections in new households despite NSW Premier Chris Minns conceding electricity is far cheaper. Victoria announced last week that all new residential properties and subdivisions which require a planning permit will only be powered by electricity from January 1. While NSW had been on the fence over the weekend, the premier has drawn a line through a similar gas ban this morning, AAP reports. "We're not pursuing that," he tells 2GB. The premier's call came a day after NSW Energy Minister Penny Sharpe said her office was still contemplating a gas ban. "We're not ruling it out all together but I've got to say it's not a priority," she told reporters on Sunday.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The NSW premier has ruled out a gas ban for new households

props.alt: A large pot with a lid and handles boiling on a gas stove

children.content: (Pexels: Oleg Magni)
New South Wales won't follow Victoria's lead in banning gas connections in new households
despite NSW Premier Chris Minns conceding electricity is far cheaper.
Victoria announced last week that all new residential properties and subdivisions which require a planning permit will only be powered by electricity from January 1.
While NSW had been on the fence over the weekend, the premier has drawn a line through a similar gas ban this morning, AAP reports.
"We're not pursuing that," he tells 2GB.
The premier's call came a day after NSW Energy Minister Penny Sharpe said her office was still contemplating a gas ban.
"We're not ruling it out all together but I've got to say it's not a priority," she told reporters on Sunday.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Four people charged with murdering Perth schoolboy Cassius Turvey are set to go to trial in the Western Australia Supreme Court in 2025. It's likely to run for eight weeks. Cassius who was 15, was allegedly attacked as he walked in Perth suburb of Middle Swan in October last year. He died 10 days later. You can read more about this story here. WARNING: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander readers are advised that the full article contains an image of a person who has died, used with the permission of their family.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Four people to stand trial in 2025 over Indigenous teen Cassius Turvey's death

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton has told reporters he has no recollection or record of being briefed by the Australian Federal Police before the former government entered into contracts with a man suspected of bribing Nauruan officials. Dutton has told reporters in Canberra this morning that he would happily co-sign a letter with the prime minister referring the matters to the National Anti-Corruption Commission. He says he is "in the crossfire" of attacks between Home Affairs Minister Clare O’Neil and her department secretary, Michael Pezzullo. You can read more about this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Peter Dutton says he's in the 'crossfire' of attacks within the Home Affairs Department

featuredLink.title: Dutton 'happy to co-sign' referral to anti-corruption watchdog over Nauru contracts

props.alt: Peter Dutton in front of a blue wall.

children.content: (ABC News)
Opposition Leader Peter Dutton has told reporters he has no recollection or record of being briefed by the Australian Federal Police before the
former government entered into contracts with a man suspected
of bribing Nauruan officials.
Dutton has told reporters in Canberra this morning that he would happily co-sign a letter with the prime minister referring the matters to the National
Anti-Corruption Commission.
He says he is "in the crossfire" of attacks between Home Affairs Minister Clare O’Neil and her department secretary, Michael Pezzullo.
You can read more about this story here:

image.altText: Peter Dutton in the prime minister's courtyard

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: The Australian share market begins its day higher ahead of tomorrow's Reserve Bank decision, which is widely expected to be a "pause" in its interest-rate-hiking cycle. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX rises as markets bet on RBA pausing interest rate hikes

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There's a big divide on what the Reserve Bank will do tomorrow — depending on whether you ask an economist, or pay attention to the market's pricing. The RBA is expected to lift rates once more by 0.25 percentage points on Tuesday, and pause for the rest of the year as inflation is still running well above the target, according to a slim majority of economists in a Reuters poll. Here's what Reuters is saying: Although the RBA has raised rates by a total of 400 basis points since May 2022, inflation was still running at 6% in the last quarter (double the upper end of the 2-3% target range). A record low unemployment rate and a rebound in house prices in Australia - one of the world's most expensive housing markets - suggests the RBA still needs to raise base borrowing costs. Most global central banks are inching closer to the end of an historic tightening campaign, including the US Federal Reserve, and economists also expect the RBA will be done soon. 36 economists were surveyed by Reuters, in a poll taken on July 26-28. Over 55% of those economists forecast the RBA to raise its official cash rate by 25 basis points to 4.35%, the highest in nearly 12 years, at its August 1 meeting. The remaining 45% expected no change to the cash rate target. But financial markets were pricing in only a one in five chance of that happening. Among major local banks, Commonwealth Bank and Westpac expected a 25 basis points hike tomorrow, while ANZ and NAB predicted a pause.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Slim majority of economists in Reuters poll anticipating RBA rate hike tomorrow

children.content: There's a big divide on what the Reserve Bank will do tomorrow — depending on whether you ask an economist, or pay attention to the market's pricing.

The RBA is expected to lift rates once more by 0.25 percentage points on Tuesday, and pause for the rest of the year as inflation is still running well above the target, according to a slim majority of economists in a Reuters poll.
Here's what
Reuters
is saying:
Although the RBA has raised rates by a total of 400 basis points since May 2022, inflation was still running at 6% in the last quarter (double the upper end of the 2-3% target range).
A record low unemployment rate and a rebound in house prices in Australia - one of the world's most expensive housing markets - suggests the RBA still needs to raise base borrowing costs.
Most global central banks are inching closer to the end of an historic tightening campaign, including the US Federal Reserve, and economists also expect the RBA will be done soon.
36 economists were surveyed by Reuters, in a poll taken on July 26-28.
Over 55% of those economists forecast the RBA to raise its official cash rate by 25 basis points to 4.35%, the highest in nearly 12 years, at its August 1 meeting.
The remaining 45% expected no change to the cash rate target.
But financial markets were pricing in only a one in five chance of that happening.
Among major local banks, Commonwealth Bank and Westpac expected a 25 basis points hike tomorrow, while ANZ and NAB predicted a pause.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Origin Energy, which is set to be taken over by a Brookfield-led consortium, said revenue from its share of the Australia Pacific LNG project (APLNG) fell 12.3% in the fourth quarter, hurt by lower prices. Oil and liquefied natural gas (LNG) prices have fallen from their 2022 peaks as slower-than-expected economic growth in key consumer China and concerns about global economic prospects cloud the outlook for fuel demand. Australia's second-largest power producer said its share of revenue from APLNG — a joint venture with ConocoPhillips and Sinopec — fell to $611 million for the three months to June 30 (compared with $697 million a year earlier). Origin, which is nearing the conclusion of its $15.35 billion takeover by a consortium led by Canada's Brookfield, said the average realised price for LNG in the quarter was $US12.24 per metric million British thermal unit (mmBtu). It's a significant drop from the price it fetched for LNG a year earlier ($US14.24 per mmBtu). By 12:10pm AEST, Origin Energy's share price was flat at $8.52. - Reuters / ABC
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Origin Energy posts 12% drop in quarterly revenue from Australia Pacific LNG

children.content: Origin Energy, which is set to be taken over by a Brookfield-led consortium, said revenue from its share of the Australia Pacific LNG project (APLNG) fell 12.3% in the fourth quarter, hurt by lower prices.

Oil and liquefied natural gas (LNG) prices have fallen from their 2022 peaks as slower-than-expected economic growth in key consumer China and concerns about global economic prospects cloud the outlook for fuel demand.

Australia's second-largest power producer said its share of revenue from APLNG — a joint venture with ConocoPhillips and Sinopec — fell to $611 million for the three months to June 30 (compared with $697 million a year earlier).

Origin, which is nearing the conclusion of its $15.35 billion takeover by a consortium led by Canada's Brookfield, said the average realised price for LNG in the quarter was $US12.24 per metric million British thermal unit (mmBtu).
It's a significant drop from the price it fetched for LNG a year earlier ($US14.24 per mmBtu).
By 12:10pm AEST, Origin Energy's share price was flat at $8.52.
- Reuters / ABC

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has begun its week slightly higher, with the industrials and energy sectors posting the largest gains. The ASX 200 index was up 0.3% by 11am AEST. Lynas Rare Earths was one of the best-perfroming stocks, after its share price jumped 4%. This was despite the company revealing its fourth-quarter revenue plunged 47% (as it was hurt by lower market prices for rare earth products during the quarter). The world's largest producer of rare earths outside of China said sales revenue was $157.5 million for the three months ended June 30 (compared with $294.5 million a year ago). On the other hand, shares of IGO fell 4.1% despite the lithium miner reporting a small increase in its June quarter sales revenue, compared to the same period last year. However, the worst performer was Silver Lake Resources. The gold miner's share price plunged 23.1% after it released quarterly results which fell below market expectations.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX lifts despite mixed performance from mining stocks

children.content: The Australian share market has begun its week slightly higher, with the industrials and energy sectors posting the largest gains.
The ASX 200 index was up 0.3% by 11am AEST.
Lynas Rare Earths
was one of the best-perfroming stocks, after its share price jumped 4%.
This was despite the company revealing its fourth-quarter revenue plunged 47% (as it was hurt by lower market prices for rare earth products during the quarter).
The world's largest producer of rare earths outside of China said sales revenue was $157.5 million for the three months ended June 30 (compared with $294.5 million a year ago).
On the other hand, shares of
IGO
fell 4.1% despite the lithium miner
reporting a small increase in its June quarter sales revenue, compared to the same period last year.
However, the worst performer was
Silver Lake Resources
The gold miner's share price plunged 23.1% after it released quarterly results which fell below market expectations.
